II. ALLEGATION:
Violation
Established?
On Saturday 9/18/21, Youth K was taken to Urgent Care for an Yes
abscess on her right thigh. The abscess was drained, and
antibiotics were prescribed. The e-script for antibiotics was sent to
LS Pharmacy which is closed on the weekends. On Sunday
evening 9/19/21, Youth K was admitted to the hospital as the
infection had spread. Youth K was not given her antibiotics on
9/19/21 because Crossroads staff did not request the e-script be
re-routed to a pharmacy that was open.
Additional Findings:
Crossroads staff did not read the hand-written Urgent Care Yes
Discharge Instructions upon Youth K’s return from the hospital and
did not monitor the youth’s wound and condition closely as the
instructions indicated.
Crossroads did not notify the licensing authority within 24 hours
after Youth K was admitted to the hospital.
Crossroads staff did not perform eye-on checks at variable
intervals not to exceed fifteen minutes per the rule.
III. METHODOLOGY

ALLEGATION:
On Saturday 9/18/21, Youth K was taken to Urgent Care for an abscess on her right
thigh. The abscess was drained, and antibiotics were prescribed. The e-script for
antibiotics was sent to LS Pharmacy which is closed on the weekends. On Sunday
evening 9/19/21, Youth K was admitted to the hospital as the infection had spread.
Youth K was not given her antibiotics on 9/19/21 because Crossroads staff did not
request the e-script be re-routed to a pharmacy that was open.
INVESTIGATION:
DCWL received this complaint on 9/28/21 transferred from another government agency.
After interviewing Staff 1 on 9/30/21, I contacted the government agency and requested
they reconsider assigning the complaint. Government Worker 1 was assigned for a joint
investigation on 9/30/21.
3

Interviews
Youth K, age 15, is a CMO youth who has been at Crossroads for five months. I
interviewed her on-site at the facility on 9/28/21. Youth K said about noon on 9/18/21,
she felt a hard spot on her right thigh that was painful. Around 2pm, Staff 1 transported
her to Independent Point Urgent Care in Clarkston. Urgent Care medical staff
administered antibiotics intravenously, made an incision on her thigh, bandaged the
wound, prescribed Cephalexin 500mg (antibiotic) every 8 hours for 10 days to begin on
9/19/21 and provided hand-written discharge instructions.
On the drive back to Crossroads from Urgent Care, Youth K said she started
experiencing “chills.” In response, Staff 1 continued to drive her directly to St. Joseph
Mercy Hospital in Pontiac where she was seen by Physician 1. Youth K said the
hospital staff drew a circle around the abscess, gave her Motrin and told her to return if
the redness spread outside of the circle. Youth K said she left the emergency room
feeling better and went straight to bed when she returned to Crossroads.
On Sun 9/19/21, Youth K said Staff 1 noticed her face was red. Staff 1 took her
temperature. looked at her incision beneath the bandage and observed the redness had
spread well beyond the circle. By this time, Youth K said she had still not received her
prescribed antibiotic that was scheduled to begin that morning. Staff 1 immediately
transported her back to St. Joseph’s and she was admitted by Physician 1. Youth K
remained on the pediatric unit from 9/19/21 – 9/22/21.
I interviewed Staff 2 on 9/28/21. She has worked at Crossroads for two months. Staff
2 worked on 9/18/21 from 8am – 2pm. Around 1pm, she said Youth K complained of a
hard bump on her thigh that sounded to her like an infection. Staff 2 reported this to
Supervisor 1 and left the facility as her shift had ended.
Supervisor 1 who worked on 9/18/21 could not be interviewed as she is no longer
employed by the facility.
I interviewed Supervisor 2 on 9/28/21. On 9/19/21, her shift began at 2pm. Supervisor
2 said she immediately began looking for the hard copy of Youth K’s antibiotic
prescription she thought had been misplaced. Supervisor 2 said that at that time, she
was unaware no paper copy existed, and that Urgent Care had sent an e-script directly
to LS Pharmacy, which she knew was closed on weekends. She said LS pharmacy is
the pharmacy Crossroads routinely uses to fill prescriptions. When prescriptions need
filling on weekends, she said a supervisor usually reminds the staff to ask medical
personnel to have them sent to Walgreen’s which is open. Around 4:30pm, Supervisor
2 said she was informed that Youth K was not feeling well so she sent her 1 back to the
hospital with Staff 1.
4

I interviewed Clinical Director (CD 1) on 9/28/21 and again collaboratively with
Government Worker 1 on 10/1/21 by phone. He has worked at Crossroads for 25
years. On 9/18/21 due to a staff shortage, he said he assumed the role of campus
Supervisor while (former) Supervisor 1 worked as Direct Care staff. CD 1 said he was
at the facility and in charge when Youth K returned from Urgent Care and the hospital
with the discharge instructions.
CD 1 said Crossroads does not employ a nurse. He admitted he did not personally
read Youth K’s discharge instructions, but he was aware of them because Staff 4 told
them what they said.
When Youth K and Staff 1 returned from the medical visits on Saturday night, CD 1 said
he knew Urgent Care sent an “e-script” to LS pharmacy, but he also thought they wrote
a paper prescription. At that time, he learned “our pharmacy” was closed on weekends,
which he said surprised him. “It was a revelation to me…Evidently this was known by
my staff. I was under the impression we also had a paper prescription (that had been
misplaced).” Rather than call Urgent Care to request a second e-script be sent to a
pharmacy that could fill it timely, Crossroads staff continued to search for a paper
prescription that did not exist. Consequently, Youth K never received her antibiotics
scheduled to begin on Sunday morning.
I interviewed Staff 1 by phone on 9/30/21. She has worked at Crossroads for three
months. Previously she was employed at an urgent care facility. Staff 1 said she
worked 2pm – 10pm on 9/18/21 and a double shift from 2pm on 9/19 to 7am on 9/20.
Staff 1 said on 9/18/21 at 2:20pm she transported Youth K to Urgent Care and St.
Joseph’s hospital. They returned to Crossroads at 7:30pm. While at Urgent Care, Staff
1 said Supervisor 1 instructed her by phone to “tell Urgent Care to send it (prescription)
to LS Pharmacy.” Upon returning to Crossroads, Staff 1 said “I told Supervisor 1 and
CD 1 that Youth K’s e-script was sent to LS pharmacy. They (CD 1 and Supervisor 1)
were aware that pharmacy was closed. I told them it was electronically sent and there
was no paper prescription.”
At 2pm on 9/19/21 when she started her shift, Staff 1 said she spoke with CD 1 and
Staff 3. “I told them to call Urgent Care and get the prescription resent to another
pharmacy. I know because I used to work at an Urgent Care. They said they’d take
care of it.” That day around 5:00pm, Staff 1 said she noticed Youth K’s face was red.
Staff 1 checked her for a fever and her temperature was 102.4 degrees. Staff 1 said
she unwrapped the youth’s bandage and observed the “redness” had spread outside
the circle. “I told Supervisor 2 she needed to go to the hospital.” Records indicate Staff
1 transported Youth K to the hospital around 6:15pm.
At the hospital visit on 9/19/21, Staff 1 said she informed Physician 1 that Youth K had
not received any antibiotics yet. According to Staff 1, “he said I’ll have to admit her. It’s
5

going to get worse. If she had taken the antibiotics, it would’ve been better, not worse.”
Staff 1 said she stayed with Youth K overnight at the hospital and was relieved by
another staff person the next morning.
I interviewed Staff 4 jointly with Government Worker 1 by phone. She has worked at
the facility for 11 years. Staff 4 normally works on another unit, but on 9/18/21, she
worked on Youth K’s unit. When Staff 1 and Youth K returned from Urgent Care and
the hospital, she heard Staff 4 mention that Youth K had a prescription to be filled. “We
typically use LS pharmacy. Knowing LS pharmacy was closed on weekends, “I asked
CD 1 where he wanted ‘this one’ to be filled. “I assumed the prescription was there…I
didn’t have an actual (paper) prescription. I wrote the info in the business (medical)
log.” I asked Staff 4 if she read the hand-written discharge instructions. She said she
did not read them and did not see anyone else read them.
Medical Documentation
Necessary Follow Up Care hand-written from Independent Point Urgent Care date
9/18/21 indicated the following:
 Keep dressing in place for 24 hours
 Once removed, cleanse the area with anti-bacterial soap and water 2-3
times daily – may apply a topical anti-infective after cleansing
 Apply warm compresses to the area 2 – 3 times daily
 Monitor closely for any increased redness, warmth or pain/swelling and
seek immediate medical care
 Cephalexin 500mg every 8 hours for 10 days – START 9/19/21
The following was noted in Youth K’s Crossroads health record by Staff 1:
9/18/21 – “Taken to urgent care for abscess on leg. Abscess was drained and
Cephalexin 500mg was prescribed for 10 days. Youth was referred to hospital for
uncontrollable shaking and examined. (At hospital) Abscess was circled with marker
and staff was told to watch to make sure redness does not spread. Youth was told to
start antibiotics on 9/19/21 and she should see improvement. If not, come back to ER
for IV meds.”
The following was noted in Youth K’s Crossroads health record by an
unidentified staff person:
9/19/21 – “Was taken to ER at St. Joe’s with 102 temperature due to infection in right
thigh. Was admitted and transferred up to pediatric floor.”
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
ANALYSIS: Crossroads staff did not read or follow Youth K’s Urgent Care
hand-written instructions received on 9/18/21. They did not fill
her prescription in a timely manner and did not monitor her
closely for increased redness, warmth or swelling until 5pm the
next evening.
Technical Assistance
When a youth returns from Urgent Care, the hospital or any
medical appointment, all instructions should be read
immediately by a supervisor on duty. The supervisor should
distribute any instructions to all staff potentially responsible for
caring for that youth until he/she receives follow-up medical
care. If the youth is prescribed medication, the supervisor on
duty should assure the prescription is filled in a timely manner.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
I was the Licensing Consultant assigned to Crossroads when Youth K was admitted to
the hospital on 9/19/21. Crossroads did not notify me of the hospitalization within 24
hours.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4150 Incident reporting.
(1) Any incident resulting in serious injury of a resident or
illness requiring inpatient hospitalization, shall be reported
to the parent/ legal guardian, responsible referring agency,
and the licensing authority as soon as possible, but not
more than 24 hours after the incident.
ANALYSIS: Crossroads did not notify the licensing authority of Youth K’s
hospitalization on 9/19/21 within 24 hours.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
A review of Youth K’s room check log dated 9/19/21 indicated eye-on checks of the
youth were completed every fifteen minutes on the quarter hour rather than at
variable intervals not to exceed fifteen minutes.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise out of the direct
supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval,
eye-on checks of residents. The time between the variable
interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
ANALYSIS: Youth K’s room check log dated 9/19/21 noted checks
completed every fifteen minutes on the quarter hour. However,
the checks were not done at variable intervals.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is received, I recommend this facility
maintain its current licensing status.
